Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing mechanistic connections between sex, foraging and parasitism along an ecological gradient
Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals of the same species often differ in important traits, and these differences are known functions of genetic and environmental influences. For most species, however, a mechanistic understanding of the origin and maintenance of individual variation is still missing. This project proposes mechanistic connections among three seemingly unrelated traits: investment in sexual versus asexual reproduction, feeding performance on rich versus poor resources, and susceptibility to parasites. The investigators hypothesize that differences in feeding rates create a causal chain of relationships that ultimately promotes the maintenance of diversity through basic ecological mechanisms. To test these ideas, the research combines monitoring of biodiversity and diseases in natural populations with laboratory experiments designed to disentangle genetic versus environmental factors shaping the traits of individuals. By determining how seemingly unrelated traits are integrated into distinct strategies, and examining how the frequency of different strategies varies along a natural ecological gradient, the research will provide novel insights into the ecological pressures maintaining phenotypic and genetic variation in natural populations.

Results from this study will significantly advance understanding of how diseases spread and how biodiversity is maintained. Diverse educational opportunities will be provided for undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral scientists, and research technicians. The investigators will develop a public lecture series, a summer science camp, and a new biology-mathematics course, and support activities focused on recruitment, retention and mentoring of students from under-represented groups in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Individuals of the same species often differ in important traits such as growth rate, vulnerability to disease, and reproductive output. We know that these differences arise as a function of both genetics and environmental influences. However, for most species, scientists still lack a comprehensive, mechanistic understanding of the creation and maintenance of these differences among individuals. This limitation inhibits our ability to understand questions involving the spread of disease and maintenance of biological diversity in nature. To enhance this mechanistic insight, this project studied how microscopic freshwater animals (zooplankton) avoid or contract deadly infectious disease while feeding on their algal resources. The central focus in this project forged new connections between traits that are associated with gathering food resources (e.g., how fast animals feed, how their guts process that food), how they allocate those resources once they have been eaten (to growth, immune system, clonal reproduction, or sexual reproduction), and vulnerability to disease. We also explored how relationships between these traits may influence the maintenance of genetic diversity. To develop and test these ideas, this project combined monitoring of biodiversity and diseases in natural populations in Michigan and Indiana with laboratory experiments for two species of zooplankton.  Our work was designed to disentangle genetic versus environmental factors shaping the traits of individuals. Plankton provide a useful model system for studying these general questions because they are easy to sample from nature, and one can readily quantify their traits in laboratory experiments.

 

We found that both genetics and the environment influence the expression of these traits, but that some genotypes were less sensitive to changes in the environment than were others. In addition, Daphnia living in different populations differ in their ability to exploit good vs. poor resources and also differ in how they allocate those resources. We also found that Daphnia collected in the spring differ in some key traits from those collected in the summer or autumn. These differences can then influence how many individuals become sick during an epidemic. We also examined how these traits influenced the relative number of adults and juveniles in a population, and how that ratio is related to the size of an epidemic. Furthermore, we found that epidemics can increase investment of hosts into sexual reproduction, temperature can strongly influence epidemics through feeding-related traits, success at growing at low food can determine a host genotype’s success during epidemics and when competing with other organisms, and disease can increase host density by depressing foraging rate (through several mechanisms involving food resources of hosts). This grant also supported research into our understanding of how species diversity within animal communities influences disease spread. Funding employed undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral scientists, and research technicians. The grant also contributed to a public lecture series, a summer science camp, development of a new bio-math course, and supported activities focused on recruitment, retention and mentoring of students from under-represented groups in STEM.
